messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Parameterized Complexity of Binary CSP: Vertex Cover, Treedepth, and Related Parameters

Paper Abstract: Abstract We investigate the parameterized complexity of Binary CSP parameterized by the vertex cover number and the treedepth of the constraint graph, as well as by a selection of related modulator-based parameters. The main findings are as follows: ‚Ä¢ Binary CSP parameterized by the vertex cover number is W‚Äã[3]Wdelimited-[]3\mathrm{W}[3]-complete. More generally, for every positive integer dùëëd, Binary CSP parameterized by the size of a modulator to a treedepth-dùëëd graph is W‚Äã[2‚Äãd+1]Wdelimited-[]2ùëë1\mathrm{W}[2d+1]-complete. This provides a new family of natural problems that are complete for odd levels of the WW\mathrm{W}-hierarchy. ‚Ä¢ We introduce a new complexity class XSLPXSLP\mathrm{XSLP}, defined so that Binary CSP parameterized by treedepth is complete for this class. We provide two equivalent characterizations of XSLPXSLP\mathrm{XSLP}: the first one relates XSLPXSLP\mathrm{XSLP} to a model of an alternating Turing machine with certain restrictions on conondeterminism and space complexity, while the second one links XSLPXSLP\mathrm{XSLP} to the problem of model-checking first-order logic with suitably restricted universal quantification. Interestingly, the proof of the machine characterization of XSLPXSLP\mathrm{XSLP} uses the concept of universal trees, which are prominently featured in the recent work on parity games. ‚Ä¢ We describe a new complexity hierarchy sandwiched between the WW\mathrm{W}-hierarchy and the AA\mathrm{A}-hierarchy: For every odd tùë°t, we introduce a parameterized complexity class S‚Äã[t]Sdelimited-[]ùë°\mathrm{S}[t] with W‚Äã[t]‚äÜS‚Äã[t]‚äÜA‚Äã[t]Wdelimited-[]ùë°Sdelimited-[]ùë°Adelimited-[]ùë°\mathrm{W}[t]\subseteq\mathrm{S}[t]\subseteq\mathrm{A}[t], defined using a parameter that interpolates between the vertex cover number and the treedepth. We expect that many of the studied classes will be useful in the future for pinpointing the complexity of various structural parameterizations of graph problems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Fixed-parameter tractability and completeness IV: On completeness for W[P] and PSPACE analogues",
        "Enumerating minimal connected dominating sets",
        "A survey of integrity",
        "Fixed-parameter tractability of (n‚àíkùëõùëòn-k) list coloring",
        "Vulnerability in graphs‚Äîa comparative survey",
        "Efficiently enumerating hitting sets of hypergraphs arising in data profiling",
        "The complexity of dependency detection and discovery in relational databases",
        "Problems hard for treewidth but easy for stable gonality",
        "List Colouring Trees in Logarithmic Space",
        "XNLP-completeness for parameterized problems on graphs with a linear structure",
        "On the complexity of problems on tree-structured graphs",
        "Parameterized problems complete for nondeterministic FPT time and logarithmic space",
        "Deciding parity games in quasi-polynomial time",
        "On the complexity of solution extension of optimization problems",
        "On product covering in 3-tier supply chain models: Natural complete problems for W[3] and W[4]",
        "Efficient fully dynamic elimination forests with applications to detecting long paths and cycles",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Universal trees grow inside separating automata: Quasi-polynomial lower bounds for parity games",
        "Improved bounds for the excluded-minor approximation of treedepth",
        "Parameterized Complexity",
        "Fundamentals of Parameterized Complexity",
        "Forbidden graphs for tree-depth",
        "The complexity landscape of decompositional parameters for ILP: Programs with few global variables and constraints",
        "An algorithmic theory of integer programming",
        "Where first-order and monadic second-order logic coincide",
        "On the space and circuit complexity of parameterized problems: Classes and completeness",
        "On the complexity of some colorful problems parameterized by treewidth",
        "On the parameterized complexity of multiple-interval graph problems",
        "Graph layout problems parameterized by vertex cover",
        "Parameterized complexity of coloring problems: Treewidth versus vertex cover",
        "Parameterized Complexity Theory",
        "Preprocessing subgraph and minor problems: When does a small vertex cover help?",
        "Complexity of KùêæK-tree structured Constraint Satisfaction Problems",
        "Space saving by dynamic algebraization based on tree-depth",
        "Improving vertex cover as a graph parameter",
        "Closing complexity gaps for coloring problems on HùêªH-free graphs",
        "Fixed-parameter complexity in AI and nonmonotonic reasoning",
        "Parameterized pre-coloring extension and list coloring problems",
        "An algorithm for the discovery of independence from data",
        "Solving connectivity problems parameterized by treedepth in single-exponential time and polynomial space",
        "Generalized coloring for tree-like graphs",
        "Succinct progress measures for solving parity games",
        "A polynomial excluded-minor approximation of treedepth",
        "Tree-depth and the formula complexity of subgraph isomorphism",
        "Can you beat treewidth?",
        "Computing treedepth in polynomial space and linear FPT time",
        "Hamiltonian cycle parameterized by treedepth in single exponential time and polynomial space",
        "Sparsity ‚Äî Graphs, Structures, and Algorithms, volume 28 of Algorithms and Combinatorics",
        "On the complexity of database queries",
        "Polynomial bounds for centered colorings on proper minor-closed graph classes",
        "On space efficiency of algorithms working on structural decompositions of graphs",
        "A faster parameterized algorithm for treedepth",
        "Constraint satisfaction with bounded treewidth revisited",
        "Tree-partite graphs and the complexity of algorithms",
        "On tree-partition-width"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Parameterized Complexity of Binary CSP: Vertex Cover, Treedepth, and Related Parameters, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
